dashboard.description: This is the overview dashboard when the app loads.

div.p: Visualizing data and building dashboards are my paintbrush and canvas. It's my art. The idea to build the Uber App came from years of mentoring consultants. I found that teaching engineers the nuts and bolts of a platform is relatively easy. However, when faced with a complex challenges or messy datasets I often see consultants get stuck:

ul.li: Who is the audience you're seeking to serve?
How do your users interact with the dashboards?
What meaningful questions are you trying to answer?
What process or approach best serves the customer's needs?

div.p: I developed this app to teach engineers how to think. Building dashboards that are interactive and well-designed boosts their impact, increases value from Splunk and makes organizations more successful by enabling them to make better data-driven decisions.

li.a: Build Better Dashboards - Tips for Improving User Experience
Which Came First: The Dashboard or the Data?
I Spent $20,000 on Uber - Here's what I learned

div.p: Start by visiting the Uber Executive Dashboard. This will give you high level insights into key metrics. It's also great way to get familiar and start playing with the data.
When you're ready for a deep dive fire up the advanced use cases. These are tough questions I came up with and used Splunk searches to answer:

ul.li: What time of year do I ride the most?
Is there a correlation between time and price?
Historical trending of total rides vs. cost?
How long do I wait around for uber?

div.p: What questions did you come up with? What additional use cases can you build with this data? I've open-sourced the code and made the data publicly available. Try developing additional use cases and contribute back to the community.
